items.item_text: 4:30 p.m. - Call Meeting to Order at the District Board Room, 4750 San Felipe Road, San Jose, CA 95135.
items.item_text_raw: 1. 4:30 p.m. - Call Meeting to Order at the District Board Room, 4750 San Felipe Road, San Jose, CA 95135.

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
1. Position Management
	 
a. Position Elimination
	 
Elimination of Senior Administrative Assistant (9MTCE0218C) in the Maintenance Department at the District Office effective 06/30/14.
	 
b. Position Establishment
	 
Establishment of Operations Coordinator, 100% FTE, (9MTCE0224C) in the Maintenance Department at the District Office effective 07/01/14. See attached job description.
	 
2. Employment
	 
a. New Hire
	 
Program Specialist, 40% FTE, (8AFFR0204C) in the Affirm Program at Evergreen Valley College effective 06/10/14.
	 
Senior Division Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (8BUSA0214C) in the Business & Workforce Development Department at Evergreen Valley College effective 06/02/14.
	 
Network Technician, 100% FTE, (8CTSS0202C) in the CTSS Department at Evergreen Valley College effective 06/09/14.
	 
	 
3. Change of Status
	 
a. Reclassification
	 
Reclassification process per the CSEA CBA Chapter 363 Article 23.1 and Article 23.3 "Reclassification will become effective July 1 of the year following the reclassification request."
	 
b.  Working Out of Class
	 
The employee is working out of class as Human Resources Assistant, 100% FTE,  (9HMRS0237C) in the Human Resources Department at the District Office effective 05/12/14 through 06/30/14.
	 
The employee is working out of class as Custodian II, 100% FTE, (7CUST0206C) at Range 75-D in the Custodial Department at San Jose City College effective 04/01/14 through 06/30/14.
	 
The employee is receiving additional pay as Senior Division Administrative Assistant (7MASC0201C) at Range 110-E in the Math & Science Department at San Jose City College effective 07/01/13 through 03/31/14.
	 
c. Promotion
	 
The employee is promoted to Campus Personnel Services Coordinator, 100% FTE, (8OASX0207C) in the Administrative Services Office at Evergreen Valley College from Senior Division Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (8HUMA0202C) in the Social Science, P.E., Arts, and Humanities Department at Evergreen Valley College effective 06/02/14. 
	 
d. Re-Employment
	 
Re-employment per the CSEA CBA Chapter 363 Article 22.2.1 " If the District reemploys a unit member as a permanent unit member under the provisions of this section, it shall disregard the break in service of the unit member and classifiy him/her as, and restore him/her to all the rights, benefits and burdens of a permanent unit member in the class to which he/she is reinstated."

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details: The Santa Clara County Health Services Workforce Collaborative project will establish a workforce collaborative designed to unify efforts of healthcare providers, workforce development organizations, labor unions, community colleges, and community based organizations in order to provide job search skills, career pathway information, and focused training (including digital literacy) to low wage workers such as medical assistants, medical information clerks and similar non-clinical healthcare occupations.  Workforce Institute has been designated as one of various project partners to develop the curriculum and train the students.  Workforce Institute is awarded $80,000 of the $150,000 grant to provide these services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Agreement between Community Health Partnership and Workforce Institute in the amount of $80,000

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Educational Code Section 5322 and Elections Code Section 13307 the Governing Board members must determine the content of the attached Specifications of the Election Order to send to the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters.
		 
In addition, on January 10, 2006, the Board approved the following policy regarding filing fees for the office of District Trustee:
		 
BP 2140 Partial Reimbursement for Candidate Filing Fees
		 
The district shall reimburse the Registrar of Voters for 3/4s of the filing fees and the candidate would pay 1/4th of the filing fees.

items.item_details: In order to aid in the efficient execution of various personnel matters by Human Resources , the Board finds it necessary to delegate its statutory powers over certain personnel actions to the Chancellor, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and/or designee.  It is, therefore, recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 052714-2 for the Delegation of Authority to the Chancellor or her designee for fiscal year 2014-2015 for resignations and hires.

items.item_details:
The District desires to enter into a lease for a certain portion of its real property located adjacent to its Evergreen Valley College campus site.  This objective can best be accomplished by having the District solicit one or more lease proposals for the site that allow flexibility in terms over and above the minimum requirements being solicited by the District, such as base rent, escalation clauses, and general description of improvements on the site.  Due to the complexity of any long-term ground lease, it would be extremely difficult to assess each proposal’s exact monetary value.  The District believes that it must consider other important factors in the proposals it expects to receive in addition to economic factors, such as the reputation and long-term financial stability of each proposed tenant, as well as each proposed tenant’s willingness to cooperate with respect to the educational and environmental impact.  Because these items are not conducive to a “highest bid” analysis, it may not be possible to ascertain which proposed tenant has tendered the “highest bid” in order to comply with the provision of California Education Code 81370.
	 
It would be in the best interest of the District to make selections that would comply with the needs of the District and the community free from the “highest bid” constraint of California Education Code 81370.
	 
California Education Code 81374 provides that final acceptance of the bid must be made within ten (10) days from the date of the opening of the bid.  Due to the complexities described above, and in more detail in the attached documents, the District may need to make full use of this ten (10) day period in order to perform a thorough analysis of each proposal.  Thus, request for a waiver at that time would be impractical and would greatly limit the District’s ability to properly analyze each proposal.
	 
As such, pursuant to the provisions of California Education Code 81370(b), the District requests a waiver, with regard to one or more long-term ground leases of the site, of the requirement described in 81370, which mandates that the District accept the highest bid received.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution #052714-3 for the Request for Waiver of California Education Code 81370 Highest Bid Requirement.
items.item_text: Resolution #052714-3 – Request for Waiver of California Education Code 81370 Highest Bid Requirement
items.item_text_raw: 3. Resolution #052714-3 – Request for Waiver of California Education Code 81370 Highest Bid Requirement

items.item_details:
The District and California School Employees Association Chapter 363 have completed negotiations for 2013-2014. The California School Employees Association ratified the tentative agreements for Articles 3, and 6.
	 
Article 3 Union Rights – 3.10 The District shall provide reasonable paid release time for a maximum of eight unit members for the purpose of meeting with the District in negotiations.
	 
Article 6 Salary – The District shall provide a 4.5% increase to be applied to the CSEA salary schedule retroactive to July 1, 2013.  Current employees are eligible for retroactive pay.
	 
Effective July 1, 2014, the parties agree to move four separate classifications from “Flat Rate” to placement on the CSEA salary schedule to an existing range and step. The four classifications are the following:
Carpenter
Electrician
Heating and Air Conditioning Mechanic, Plumber
Painter
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the District and California School Employees Association Chapter 363 tentative agreements.

items.item_details:
The purpose of this presentation is to provide a summary regarding the implementation of the District’s Strategic Priorities established by the Board of Trustees for the 2013-2014 Academic Year. These priorities represent the work-plan established by the Board in conjunction with the Chancellor in order to advance the Mission and Vision of the District, which includes the following:
	 
San Jose Evergreen Community College District
Strategic Goals 2013 to 2016
I.   Student Success
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will improve student success through enhanced educational services and programs and strengthened community engagement.
	 
II.  Total Work Environment
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will promote a total work environment that contributes to the success and development of its students and employees.
	 
III.  Workforce and Economic Development
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will respond to the workforce needs of the Silicon Valley.
	 
IV.  Organizational Effectiveness and Sustainability
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will develop systems that promote institutional effectiveness and fiscal sustainability.
	 
V.   Technology
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will invest in information technology solutions that enhance the learning environment and support student success.
	 
VI.  Communications
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District will engage in proactive communication with internal and external audiences to improve stakeholder satisfaction
items.item_text: State of the District 2013-2014 Academic Year
items.item_text_raw: 1. State of the District 2013-2014 Academic Year

items.item_details:
The finalized Redesign Report 2013-2017 is being presented to the Board of Trustees by the Chancellor and her Executive Team .  The document provides a detailed explanation of the planning process, collaboration and analysis that led to the development of the staffing plans.  It is important to note that the term "Redesign" was consciously selected to differentiate from standard restructuring exercises.
 
	The goal, as directed by the Board of Trustees and implemented by the Chancellor, was to make the most effective use of staff and their skills in direct relationship to the current and future needs of the District as established in the Vision and Mission Statements adopted by the Board.
	 
The document includes revised organizational charts and information regarding a phasing-in process that is dependent on need and resource availability.  Cost charts are included for Phase I, II, and III of the process.  Priorities were determined by using a student-centered approach and the Board's Policy on Student Success. 
	 
The Redesign Report represents a strategic planning document that provides a structure and a process that lends itself to future modification based on changing needs while continuing to focus on "student success" as the primary point of departure.
items.item_text: Redesign Report 2013-2017
items.item_text_raw: 2. Redesign Report 2013-2017

items.item_details:
The revised Managers, Supervisors, & Confidential Employees Handbook is being submitted as an information item for the Board of Trustees to review.
	 
This handbook was first adopted in January 1984 and has not been updated or revised since that time.  There has been significant regulatory rules and provisions that have changed that affect employees.
	 
Going forward, a review of the document shall be performed regularly to ensure currency and to be reflective of the rights and privileges afforded to this employee group.
	 
The handbook shall be submitted at the next regularly scheduled Board meeting, June 10, 2014,  with a recommendation to adopt.

items.item_details:
As part of its annual call for award nominations, the Association of Community College Trustees (ACCT) has two association awards that are of interest to the Board of Trustees: the Trustee Leadership award and the Equity and Diversity award. The submission date for nominations is June 16, 2014.  At this meeting, the Board of Trustees will discuss any nominations they wish to submit and will direct staff to prepare the nomination packets, which will be submitted to the Board for approval at the June 10 meeting.
	 
The Trustee Leadership award honors an individual who had made a significant contribution as a lay trustee to promote the community college concept. Any trustee or former trustee of an ACCT member two-year postsecondary institution is eligible to receive this award. Currently serving ACCT Board members are not eligible. Criteria for this award include:
	 
Has the trustee served as an officer of the college's board of trustees?
In addition to service on the board of trustees, in what capacity has the trustee participated in community life (i.e. civic, clubs, public office, etc.)?
What has the trustee initiated or helped to develop in the area of innovative programs used in two-year postsecondary institutions?
Has the trustee served on technical or special committees serving two-year postsecondary education?
How has the trustee been a factor in influencing legislation for two-year postsecondary institutions, and how has the trustee been active in communication and advocacy with state and national legislators?
What has the trustee contributed overall to the two-year postsecondary concept, and how did this affect the college's total impact on the community, state, or nation?
How has the trustee provided leadership in helping to solve challenges facing two-year postsecondary education?
How has the trustee been active in developing, organizing, or supporting state two-year postsecondary associations, and what kind of leadership role has the trustee played in state, regional or national associations?
Has the trustee given presentations or published articles on two-year postsecondary education?
	 
The Equity and Diversity award recognizes exemplary commitment by a community, technical or junior college governing board and its chief executive officer as a group, an individual trustee, or a trustee and chief executive officer to achieve equity in the college's education programs and services and in the administration and delivery of those programs and services. Any governing board and chief executive officer, an individual trustee, or a trustee and president of an ACCT member two-year post-secondary institution board or state board for two-year postsecondary institutions is eligible to receive this award. Currently serving ACCT board members are not eligible. Criteria for this award include:
	 
Demonstrable evidence of leadership in setting policies, championing an environment of inclusivity, and ensuring results for the success and enhancement and expansion of opportunities for women, underrepresented and underserved communities (expansion of people of color, LGBT and any other underrepresented population):
How does the college define equity within the college's service district?
Identify at least one program that promotes access and completion to an underserved community.
Describe programs aimed at successful completion, transfer and/or gainful employment.
Data: provide data on the impact of the identified program(s).
Employment and promotion (i.e. commit to employing a diverse staff, provide resources and an environment for all students to succeed)
Engagement of board of trustees, committees, advisory groups of the college, student groups and community based organizations (i.e. actively seek diverse representation).
